channel.title: Lessons Learned on juri.strumpflohner
channel.description: Recent content in Lessons Learned on juri.strumpflohner

item.title: Lessons Learned: Don't Expose EF Entities to the Client Directly
item.description: When we refactored our main application architecture, moving from an ASP.net WebForms app to a rich client JavaScript application with an ASP.net MVC REST backend, one of our main goals was to keep things as simple as possible.

item.title: Don't Underestimate the Trouble Caused by URLs in Emails
item.description: At a first glance, the title might seem strange, but wait. The company I'm working at creates e-government solutions, so the target audience are the citizens, from the young, very computer-literate ones to the more elderly (and often, but not always) less computer-literate ones :).

item.title: Juri Goes GIT - First Steps
item.description: Yes, I'm going "git" ;). An inherent part of structured, well organized working is to have your stuff under version control (1st point on the Joel Test).

item.title: Testing Your SUT Against Exceptions
item.description: When you test your method for exceptions (which is good practice) the usually naive approach - which btw I was following myself till today - is to wrap your method under test with an appropriate try-catch and set a boolean.

item.title: Presentation: Dropbox Startup Lessons Learned
item.description: An interesting presentation by the Dropbox founder Drew Houston about Dropbox startup lessons learned. Also if you don't plan to create any startup it is still interesting to see some of the strategies that have been applied and which finally made Dropbox as successful as it is - in a market which btw already seemed to be saturated.

item.title: Smelly Code: Eager Test
item.description: This post shows a common code smell in unit tests also mentioned in the xunit test patterns book, namely "Eager tests". Original, smelly code public void testSaveSession(){

item.title: Lessons Learned: Make your ListItemCollection Linq Queryable
item.description: I love Linq! In my opinion it is one of the best features that have ever been added to C#, making developers extremely more productive.
